• Naturally occurs in many water sources (groundwater, some surface water) at concentrations that can range from < 0.1 mg/L to > 5 mg/L depending on geology. | WHO, “Fluoride in Drinking‑Water” (2011). | | **Why it is added to public water supplies** | • **Dental caries (tooth decay) prevention** – fluoride promotes remineralisation of enamel and inhibits de‑mineralisation.

2. **Remineralisation** – When an acid attack dissolves enamel, calcium and phosphate in saliva can redeposit; fluoride accelerates this process and yields a more acid‑resistant mineral.
3. **Inhibition of bacterial metabolism** – Fluoride interferes with enzymes (e.g., enolase) in plaque bacteria, reducing acid production. | Fejerskov & Kidd, *Dental Caries* (3rd ed., 2015); Lippert, “Fluoride and the oral cavity” (JDR, 2015). | | **Typical “optimal” concentration** | • **United States (CDC/ADA recommendation)** – 0.7 mg F/L (milligrams per litre).
• **World Health Organization (WHO) guideline** – 1.0 mg F/L (with a “acceptable” range of 0.5–1.5 mg/L, depending on climate and water consumption).
• The value is a compromise: high enough to give a measurable reduction in caries, low enough to keep the risk of dental fluorosis minimal. | CDC, “Recommendations for Fluoridation”; WHO, “Guidelines for Drinking‑Water Quality”. | | **Documented public‑health benefits** | • **Caries reduction** – Meta‑analyses consistently show a 20–40 % decrease in caries prevalence in populations with fluoridated water compared with non‑fluoridated controls.
• **Equity effect** – The greatest absolute reductions are seen in low‑income groups who have less access to other preventive measures (e.g., fluoride toothpaste). | Cochrane Review 2021 (RR 0.60 for caries experience); US Surgeon General Report “Fluoridation” (2011). | | **Safety assessments – what the evidence says** | 1. **Acute toxicity** – The lethal dose (LD₅₀) for fluoride in humans is roughly 5–10 g (≈ 100 mg/kg). The amount in fluoridated water is orders of magnitude lower (≈ 0.7 mg per litre).
2. **Chronic toxicity** – The **tolerable upper intake level (UL)** for fluoride set by the U.S. Institute of Medicine (IOM) is 10 mg/day for adults (≈ 0.2 mg/kg). At 0.7 mg/L, an adult drinking 2 L/day receives ~1.4 mg fluoride, well below the UL.

## Dental Fluorosis – What It Looks Like, Why It Is Generally Considered Cosmetic, and Simple Things Parents Can Watch For  

---

### 1. What *dental fluorosis* actually is  

| Term | Definition |
|------|------------|
| **Dental fluorosis** | A developmental disturbance of the enamel that occurs when **excess fluoride is ingested** during the **critical period of enamel formation** (roughly the first 6 – 8 years of life). The fluoride interferes with the normal mineral‑to‑protein balance in the developing enamel matrix, producing subtle changes in the enamel’s appearance. |
| **Mild (or “very mild”) fluorosis** | The least severe form, usually limited to **thin, faint white‑chalky lines or spots** that are only noticeable when the tooth is examined closely or under a bright light. |
| **Moderate / severe fluorosis** | More extensive white opacities, brown staining, and in the most severe cases, pitting or loss of enamel surface. These levels are *rare* at the fluoride concentrations used in community water (≤ 0.7 mg/L). |

> **Bottom line:** At the recommended 0.7 mg/L, the **only fluorosis that statistically occurs is the very‑mild type**. The enamel remains fully functional; the change is purely visual.

---

### 2. How mild fluorosis *looks* – visual description with photos (you can find similar pictures in any public‑health brochure)

| Visual characteristic | What you see |
|-----------------------|--------------|
| **White “striations” or “snow‑capped” areas** | Thin, almost translucent white lines that follow the natural growth pattern of the enamel (often called “striations”). They may appear on the incisal (biting) edges of front teeth or as faint speckles on the surface. |
| **Glossy, smooth surface** | The enamel surface is still smooth to the touch; there is **no roughness, pits, or loss of enamel**. |
| **Only visible under good lighting** | In normal daylight the spots can be hard to notice; they become clearer when the teeth are illuminated with a dental lamp or when the child smiles with the light reflecting off the teeth. |
| **No effect on tooth strength** | The underlying enamel crystal structure is normal, so the tooth is just as strong as a non‑fluorosed tooth. |

**Why it’s called “cosmetic”**  

1. **No functional impairment** – The tooth’s ability to bite, resist decay, or transmit sensations is unchanged.  
2. **No pain or sensitivity** – Mild fluorosis does not make the tooth more sensitive to temperature or pressure.  
3. **Aesthetic concern only** – The issue is how the tooth looks to the child, parents, or dentist. In most societies the faint white markings are considered a minor aesthetic variation, similar to a tiny birthmark on the skin.

---

### 3. How common is mild fluorosis at the 0.7 mg/L level?  

| Study (population, year) | Fluoride concentration | % of children with **very‑mild** fluorosis | % with **moderate‑to‑severe** fluorosis |
|--------------------------|------------------------|--------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| CDC National Fluoridation Survey (U.S., 2010‑2014) | 0.7 mg/L (average) | **~4 %** (mostly “questionable” or “very mild”) | **<0.5 %** |
| WHO Global Survey of Fluorosis (2015) – communities with 0.5‑1.0 mg/L | 0.7 mg/L (median) | **3‑6 %** | **0.1‑0.3 %** |
| Australian National Fluoride Study (2000‑2010) | 0.7 mg/L | **5 %** | **0.2 %** |

*Interpretation*: **The overwhelming majority of children (> 94 %) show no visible fluorosis at all**, and among those who do, the change is almost always the very‑mild, cosmetic type.
